bibl.title: Letter from Mrs. George Carroll to Philip Showalter Hench, February 19, 1954

div1.p: Mrs. Carroll informs Hench that unless he has the written consent from the daughters of the late James Carroll, he will not be permitted to examine any papers.

div1.head: Letter from Mrs. George Carroll to Philip Showalter Hench, February 19, 1954
div1.p:
I talked with my
lawyer yesterday and he
said I should not allow
access to those records
without the written consent
of the others. Not true I saw her
lawyer. He said he'd tell
her to let me copy anything & everything wanted she
means gave them to me
without sisters
consent

I regret that you had to
make this trip in vain
but I did not know where
you were staying so I could
not notify you.

As you remember, I
told you yesterday, it would
be better for you to call
me before coming out
so that I could let you
know what the lawyer
advised.

If you can contact
the sisters and get
their written consent,
you can notify me
accordingly.

I am sorry things
turned out like thus
but I did not know
it would be this way
when you were here
yesterday.
